metadata.synopsis: Isa (Élodie Bouchez) and Marie (Natacha Régnier) bond while working in a French sweatshop and soon begin sharing an apartment that Marie is watching for a hospitalized mother and daughter. Marie, hoping to avoid a life of struggle and poverty, takes up with Chriss (Grégoire Colin), a nightclub owner whose most attractive asset is his money. Isa recognizes the ultimate futility of the relationship and tries to keep Marie away from him, but her interference puts their friendship at risk.

reviews: Two unforgettable characters are revealed, and the truth resonates powerfully through their stories.
Allows the viewer to not only see, but experience the pain of these characters.
Zonca's lyrical cinema verite style magnifies the small tensions and flare-ups that can blow apart a friendship in the blink of an eye.
The dreamlife of Angels (La Vie rve des anges) is a story of capitalistic and sexual exploitation, rage, rebellion, and the search for meaning in everyday things.
Frank, intimate, touching, with an emotional immediacy that is killing.
[Bouchez and Regnier have] fleshed out portraits of a depth rarely seen on screen.
It mopes around most of the time with not much to say.
Heralds a humanist cinema that neither shortchanges our minds nor cheapens what's in our hearts.
It's so graceful and intelligent and complicated in its depiction of human interaction that it takes the notion of a remarkably assured directorial debut to a new level.
Zonca shows an extraordinary ability to get into the female psyche.
Not overly bad, just not a lot going on in this sleepy melodrama.
